titleStmt.title: Vilhelm Voight Broch informs about the deportation of Anna Wimmer from Vienna to Poland in 1942

sourceDesc.bibl: Rigsarkivet, 37.H1, Gestandtskab Østrig 1967, aflevering 1. Original in Danish.

note.p: The head of a county or a country region in occupied German territories. Subordinate to a Kreishauptmann.

person.note: Beile Stark (born 1888) and her son Rudolf Stark(born 1920) were deported from Vienna to the Litzmannstadt Ghetto(Łódź)on October 23, 1941

note.p: Vilhelm Voight Broch, Danish diplomate and consul general in Vienna.
Anna Wimmer (1884-1942), Anna Wimmer was transported from Vienna to the Litzmannstadt Ghetto (Łódź) on October 15 1941. Anna Wimmer did not survive the Holocaust.

Directly after the “Anschluss” of Austria to Nazi Germany in 1938 the National Socialists closed the Vienna Jewish Community (IKG - Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien) and imprisoned the leading Jewish functionaries in concentration camps. The IKG was restructured and reopened in May 1938. Due to the increasing exclusion, disenfranchisement and dispossession of the Austrian Jews, one of the most important tasks for the IKG was the care of the impoverished Jewish population and the organisation of mass emigration for those fleeing. These tasks could only be carried out through the forced collaboration with the Central Office for Jewish Emigration. With the end of the mass deportations at the end of October 1942, the IKG was disbanded. A so-called “Council of Elders of the Jews of Vienna” took over their responsibilities for the roughly 8000 Jews still in Vienna. In contrast to other areas of occupied Europe, the organisation was able to continue its activities until the end of the war.

body.p: In response to your letter of 22 December, in which you request the Consulate General to search for your sister, Miss Anna Wimmer, assuming that you are a Danish citizen, we hereby inform you that it is true that Miss Wimmer left for Poland together with a Family Stark in October of 1941.

At the Israeli Cultural Commemoration Centre, Vienna, I., Seitenstettengasse 2/4, the Consulate General has learned that you can contact 'An den Aeltesten der Juden, Lizmannstadt, Ghetto, Polen’, which then probably through the Jewish organizations in question will be able to provide information about your sister's present address.
The Consulate General shall add that no further action can be taken in this matter, unless special instructions are received from the Royal Commission.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Copenhagen.
P. G. V. Vice Consul, signed V.V. Broch
